title: A Champion Can Be Pure Evil But Still Be Likeable
body:
Everyone says that {{champion:112}}  is the perfect villain and something that every bad guy should be designed after but I honestly think that's not true. A character can be a extremely evil without any redeeming qualities or a troubled past but still someone you can cheer for and find to be likeable as a champion.

{{champion:119}} {{champion:202}} {{champion:222}} {{champion:240}} {{champion:223}}  are the best example for this imo.

replies.body:
Agreed.   I think a villain must have the same character depth and thematic qualities as a hero.   They must be entertaining, a little surprising, and have layers.   A bland good guy is just as terrible as an overly arch bad guy.     It's bad writing.    Additionally, video game characters should also be larger-than-life and somewhat understandable within the first 10 secs.  

Regardless thanx for putting 3 of mah champs on ur list!{{sticker:zombie-nunu-hearts}}

This is something I feel is very important, and I think that the last few stories that came out lacked a bit of a really evil villain: warwick is a feral hunter, but he wants to become a better person (or at least make up for the wrong he did), viktor has very valid reasons and just "wants to help" (i dislike Jayce a lot more, could we ever see *him* turn evil?), mundo is just mad. Singed... dunno, maybe he's still "evil", in a mad scientist way, it depends on how much he does for the sake of scienceTM and how much he revels in inflicting pain and suffering to the subjects of his experiments. Going back we had Renekton who's mad, Camille's brother who's manipulative and a bit childish but not really evil... I think Xerath is the only one who definitely does act for what I'd say is evil, but with a sensible reason (withouth being too sympatethic either).
EDIT: I forgot about Gangplank! I loved him in Burning Tides, I think he's a good example of an evil character who's lots of cool! (I hope Swain ends up in a similar spot <3) /EDIT

What do you think about this? You're clearly trying to give villains motivations, but to me this often pushes them a bit away from the villain role and makes them more likable (which isn't something bad for itself, but don't you think you'll run out of really evil characters in your world?)

ps: I'm actually looking foreward to seeing some Demacia stories, I have a feeling you're turning Noxians into a bit more likable people, and I guess you'll show the more shadowy side of their "good" counterparts from Demacia... ;)

We want all the characters  (villains included) to have clear, strong _motivations_, and be _entertaining_.   

Actually both _Evil_ and _Likeable_ are dangerous terms for character creation.   (It often comes up in development meetings with new team members).
 "Likeable" and "Evil" mean different things to different people--- often with moral underpinning. 
(I use the terms _empathetic_ and _selfish_)

_Selfish_ is what I use as a moral spectrum.   While _empathetic_ relates to the character's clarity and execution. (I.e. do I "grok" his motivations)

 Now Jhin was designed to be a villain-- but also to shed light on Zed and Ionia.  I would argue Jhin is _entertaining_.  You understand what _motivates_ him.  You can _empathise_ with him-- buuuuttt ...  it feels a bit icky to do so.  Because he is so astonishingly _selfish_. You have to use the parts of your personality you're probably not proud of.  (Particularly the psychological relationship between arrogance and insecurity)  

So is Jhin _likeable_?

IF you mean is Jhin _entertaining_?   yes.
IF you mean can you _empathise_ with him?  yes.
But if you mean is he a good person?  Would you like to meet him? Is he pleasant? Is he friendly? Nice?    Nooooooo.  None of those.  He is a _selfish_- a-hole. 

The difference you're describing with Warwick and Victor is an attempt to make them less selfish.  Their motivations are less clearly evil-- and we understand they might be capable of redemption.

> Comets of white blue flame leapt from Xerath’s outstretched arms, arcing like boulders from a war-machine. The first fell to earth in the market, exploding like a falling star. Searing fire detonated from the impact. Burning bodies were hurled into the air like blackened kindling. Fiery winds carried Xerath’s spiteful laughter, an ageless insanity that reveled in the pain of others.

I love Bloodline, read at least for 3 times, and beg for sequel, but something makes me worried about Xerath in the end of Shurima act. Xerath, with this personality, is  abandoned to another imprison or death.

If you ask me, after Azir's defeat, Xerath's goals would be breaking the sigils of bind he has, getting more and more powerful, learning the secrets of magic in next level and conquering Runeterra (with this morale).

Also, it is interesting to see a being who says ''emotions are only distractions'' is oriented mostly by emotions like pleasure, hatred, anger, envy etc.

Do you guys ever label champs under the D&D alignment chart to see to try and see if they are truly good or evil

Nope.  
We find it's usually not helpful for the creative process.  It always makes for a fun discussion-- but it quickly derails into a philosophical discussion that doesn't advance understanding of the champion. 
 -- That said, it sometimes comes up (often during lunch).    
(for instance depending on your view of good and law,  Illaoi is arguably every form of alignment in the D&D system.)  

  Instead of D&D alignment we tend to look for an early "hook" that's understandable.    
 --i.e.  Tahm Kench is certainly Lawful Evil.   But that doesn't tell the team as much useful of information as "Tahm is like an evil used car salesman."

> "Tahm is like an evil used car salesman."

Saleswoman Illaoi and Salesman Tahm Kench? Sorry, I have no regrets as I dislike her void skin very much and I enjoy joke skins a lot more than regular ones.

Honestly I just want a Tahm Kench skin that captures his original feel instead of turning him into a joke. The Urf one is not only silly, but it makes him sky blue. The chef one is less silly, but it's still not that slimy sort of evil that his base skin is. Also that shade of orange is _eye searing_.

Like most naturalistic gods and priests thereof, Illaoi would probably tend towards true neutral. Nagakebouros is in many ways a lifeforce deity, more energy given name/will than a mind given power (gods tend to break down into humanoids with characteristics who ascend to power and personifications with vague characteristics who are/represent power already existent and Nagakebouros is the latter). This is also somewhat apparent if you look at her ideals/motivations. They are deeply personal/interpersonal (growth of the self and others) and care very little for greater purpose (unless there is something about Nagakebouros we don't know). Good grows for greater ends, evil grows for its own ends, but Illaoi tells us to grow for the sake of growth, more akin to a plant or wild animal than a hero or a villain.

Eh, I've disagreed on Rioters ideas of the alignment pool before, and I'll d so again with Jinx.  She's all about mindless joyous destruction, and Rioters have admitted that people have died in her little sprees.  Just because she doesn't care, or wasn't specifically trying to kill anyone doesn't make her suddenly not an evil murderer, willing to put her enjoyment above the very lives of others directly (or indirectly) in her way.

She's Harley Quinn, basically.  They're both fun, and bubbly, and oh so charismatic.  But they've murdered for no reason.  They're pretty firmly Chaotic Evil, just with the personality to not seem so negative about it.

It's not entirely logical to say Jinx is simply Harley Quinn.
Harley Quinn is by A LOT of standards not Chaotic Evil, she's a lot more complex then that.

She didn't kill Black Canary when she found out she was pregnant, and even went on to check up on Black Canary and bring her gifts. 
She saved countless abused animals.
She has attempted multiple times to kill the Joker, and then gone back to loving him. 
She saved a girl from being beaten and raped. 
She on the other hand, has killed innocent people when she was working with the Joker.

Jinx on the other hand is nuts for the sake of being nuts.
As far as we know she does not have any true motives behind all of the chaos she creates besides it being fun. 
Riot has described Jinx as seeing other people through a cloud of dust, she's dis-associative. 

You can't go and claim these characters are Chaotic Evil when not all of the stuff they do is evil. 
Harley Quinn has done a lot of bad things, but on the other hand she has done a lot of good things. 
Jinx has done a lot of bad things, but not for the sake of being bad but because she's bonkers.

Well, yes I can. Because the alignment system was never meant to mean that the character can only perform actions that that are always fitting their box on the chart. Hell, Gary Gygax said that characters are more complex and evil people still have their own principles and loved ones. That doesn't suddenly stop them from being evil. Saving a puppy doesn't suddenly wipe the slate clean when you've got a couple hundred innocents you murdered. If it did the entire alignment system would break every time a character had any complexity at all. 

Also, come on man.  The pregnant Canary bit isn't even canon. It's from a comic about a video game. Admittedly a very good comic, but that's like saying Superman is lawful evil because of it. That's not the "real" Superman, nor the "real" Harley.

Well going off of that logic you can't go and claim just because Jinx and Harley have killed people it immediately makes them Chaotic Evil.
The phrases goes both ways. 

Killing a few people doesn't immediately make you pure evil or Chaotic Evil for that matter. 
Garen has killed people knowing he'd be ending lives, Jinx does it amongst her own mayhem un-intentionally. 
She's Chaotic, but she's by no means evil. 
There's clearly no convincing you but that's just my two cents. 
 
You can't argue canon when DC Has countless different time-lines, worlds and reboots all within themselves. 
Unlike the Marvel cinematic Universe there is no one linear timeline that defines the DC universe.
It's a multi-verse system.  
In that verse yes, it is canon.

Context my good man, context. Harley has killed innocents because she was bored. Or because the Joker told her to. Or because Ivy told her to.  Or because they inconvenienced her in some way (one guy asked for her to pay for her ice cream cone got his head smashed in). 

Garen, at least in the original lores, killed enemy combatants to defend his people and home. I have no idea what his new motivation is, but I'd guess something similar. 

One is clearly evil. And she is unrepentant of that evil. She hasn't gone through a grand character change that goes "Yeah, that horrible, terrible shit that should damn me to the DC version of Hell was wrong. I won't do that anymore."  (Outside of one good future elseworld story anyway) 

She still actively kills people for the laughs. Only currently she's trying to get out from Joker's thumb while she does it.

I'm hardly a man, but I don't think Context adds to your side of the argument. 

You're looking at in a vacuum and then lumping the characters into a linear scale as result.

Context, my good non-man, context.  

Lumping into a scale is literally the point of the alignment system.  Lumping together characters with similar motivations and actions.  Of which, Harley (and Jinx) fit the descriptions provided for the Chaotic Evil alignment.

Does this mean they cannot be complex characters? Hell no, some amazing characters fit the Chaotic Evil alignment.

Does this mean they can never ever do anything good?  Also, no.  Unless they're in some sort of magic bound that they can only perform actions that fit their alignment, say if they had take the Paladin's Oath.  Or Paladin of Slaughter if we want to go the CE route, though holy crap their oath is a mess.  But not every character is a Paladin of Slaughter.  And hell, even the Joker has performed a good act before.  He once paid for a minions messy divorce.  Does that suddenly make him not in the running for most evil character in DC?  No, hell no.  He then raped the wife.  But still, the alignment system is about painting in broad strokes and generalities.  And Harley fits pretty squarely into Chaotic Evil.

Except that the argument can be applied both ways.
You could argue for either with the right context and word twisting. 

Imo she fits perfectly in the Chaotic Neutral category.
She's a bad person, but she still does good things. 

You're still looking at in a vacuum.

No, I'm looking at the definitions provided by Gygax.  Chaotic Neutral specifically does not have a disregard for life, while Chaotic Evil does.  And her actions she's taken during her crime sprees definitely shows her with a disregard for life.  Murder of innocents is considered one of the unforgivables in the D&D alignment system, of which Harley is outrageously guilty.  She has killed more people in comics than any known serial killer in the real world.  

But, again, that doesn't mean she can't save someone if she wants to.  Evil can still have friends, evil can still have (often warped) morals.  

Remember, Neutral, is us.  Neutral are the random people in the street who may prefer Good, but don't really actively pursue it.  Except maybe volunteering at a soup kitchen or something equally trivial.  Evil are the ones that kill for pleasure, which she is most certainly guilty of doing.
